> Richard i=
s spot-on in his observations, of course.
> 
> I'm thinking that it's worth=
 noting that "Ko-Kinko" can tend to be a big box
> in which to sort anythin=
g old (Ko) made of soft metal (Kinko) rather than
> iron. So the materials =
can cover the gamut from brass, bronze, yamagane
> ("impure" copper), more =
refined copper, and even shakudo, and the techniques
> can range from cast,=
 forged, sanmai, various surface treatments, zogan, etc.
> Some pieces can =
be easily classified by "school" in the roughest sense of
> the word - cast=
 guards are invariably "Kagamishi" - and somewhat more
> decorated guards l=
ike your sanmai get called "Ko-Kinko" like they are some
> pre-Kinko (fancy=
) guards. In fact some get further classified as Ko-Goto or
> Ko-Mino when =
they look like the antecedent of those well defined schools
> that fully fl=
ower as we move closer to Edo period.
> 
> My own recent area of interest h=
as been "tachikanagushi" guards which are
> soft metal thought (by some) to=
 be made by tachi makers who also made
> fittings to go with the blades the=
y made, which is (I think) an interesting
> speculation without much empiri=
cal evidence. In any case you can see much of
> that collection on Boris Ma=
rkhasin's website, on the consignment page, at
> yamabushiantiques.com.
> 
=

le
> enjoyment of beautiful art objects, but I approach this study more fro=
m an
> art angle.
